title: RL30957
content: This CRS Report discusses U.S. security assistance for Taiwan, focusing on policy issues for Congress and listing defense sales approved since 1990. The Taiwan Relations Act governs U.S. arms sales to Taiwan, emphasizing the need to provide defensive arms and maintain the capacity to resist any nonpeaceful means to determine Taiwan's future. The Taiwan Relations Act emphasizes the need to provide defensive arms to Taiwan to maintain its self-defense capability. It specifies a congressional role in decision-making on security assistance, with the President and Congress determining the nature and quantity of defense articles and services based on Taiwan's needs. In a crisis, the Act allows for the provision of necessary defense assistance. The Taiwan Relations Act requires the President to promptly inform Congress of any threats to Taiwan's security or U.S. interests. The Act established the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) to carry out embassy functions in Taipei. AIT implements policy directed by the Departments of Defense and State, and the NSC. Congress oversees major arms sales notifications and policies implemented by the President since 1982. President Reagan agreed to reduce arms sales to Taiwan in 1982 but clarified that sales would continue as per the TRA for peaceful purposes. Reagan extended "Six Assurances" to Taipei, reaffirming that arms sales to Taiwan would continue as per the Taiwan Relations Act for peaceful purposes. Despite the absence of a defense treaty, Taiwan has been a significant recipient of U.S. arms sales, ranking among the top recipients globally. Deliveries of U.S. defense articles and services to Taiwan totaled $4.3 billion in the 2004-2007 period and $2.9 billion in 2008-2011. Taiwan ranked fourth in arms sales recipients in 2004-2007 and fifth in 2008-2011. In 2011, Taiwan ranked eighth worldwide in receiving $800 million worth of U.S. defense articles and services. Taiwan also ranked sixth globally in agreements in 2011 alone, with $1.6 billion worth of agreements. The Pentagon expanded the military relationship with Taiwan after the Taiwan Strait crisis in 1995-1996, focusing on strategy, training, logistics, and command and control. Taiwan's F-16 fighter pilots have trained at Luke Air Force Base. In 2004, Taiwan's Minister of Defense wanted to withdraw F-16 fighter pilots trained at Luke Air Force Base since 1997. The Defense Department emphasized the importance of the training program to develop skilled pilots. Strategic talks between the U.S. and Taiwan on national security have been ongoing since 1997, with the 11th round taking place in September 2005. The 11th round of strategic talks between the U.S. and Taiwan took place in late September 2005, following a postponement by the Bush Administration to accommodate PRC ruler Hu Jintao's visit to Washington. The talks focused on U.S. concerns about Taiwan's self-defense capability and included discussions on defense and security matters. Deputy Secretary of Defense Paul Wolfowitz and Assistant Secretary of Defense Peter Rodman emphasized the need for Taiwan's military to strengthen civilian control, enhance jointness, and improve readiness and interoperability among its services. The Pentagon assessed Taiwan's defense needs from 1997 to early 2004, identifying problems in its ability to defend against aircraft, ballistic missiles, and cruise missiles. Congress could request reports or briefings on these assessments to improve readiness, planning, and interoperability among Taiwan's military services. In September 2000, the Pentagon conducted a classified assessment of Taiwan's naval defense needs, finding that Taiwan required the Aegis radar system, Kidd-class destroyers, submarines, anti-submarine sonar array, and P-3 anti-submarine aircraft. In December 2000, the Defense Department issued a "Report to Congress on Implementation of the TRA," and in January 2001, a Pentagon team examined Taiwan's command and control, air force equipment, and air defense capabilities. In September 2001, a Defense Department team visited Taiwan to assess its army as part of arms sales talks. In August 2002, a U.S. military team studied Taiwan's Po Sheng command and control program. In November 2002, another U.S. team assessed Taiwan's Marine Corps and security at ports and harbors. In 2007-2009, Taiwan conducted a Joint Defense Capabilities Assessment with U.S. assistance. In 2010, the Defense Department began detailed studies of Taiwan's joint defense transformation. In 2009, Congress directed the Defense Secretary to assess Taiwan's air defense forces, including F-16 fighters. The Defense Department assessed Taiwan's air defense forces, including its F-16 fighters, in a report submitted to Congress in February 2010. The study found that Taiwan's combat aircraft were not all operationally capable, with the F-5 fighters reaching the end of their service life and the Indigenous Defense Fighters lacking sustained sortie capability. Taiwan recognized the need for sustainable replacements for its obsolete and problematic aircraft. The Bush and Obama Administrations did not accept Taiwan's request for new F-16s for almost four years before a comprehensive assessment was conducted. The assessment led to the Pentagon considering Taiwan's air defense needs, with Congress directing the Defense Secretary to submit a classified report on Taiwan's Air Force capabilities by December 1, 2013. The Defense Department assessed Taiwan's Air Force capabilities by December 1, 2013, submitting a classified report on January 3, 2014. The balance of forces across the Taiwan Strait has shifted in favor of the PRC, with Taiwan no longer enjoying dominance of the airspace.
